awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Understanding Extreme Fire Weather Hazards and Improving Resilience in Coastal Santa Barbara, California
awd_abstract_narration:
Wildfires at the wildland-urban interface pose significant hazards to people and the environment and cost billions of dollars. Santa Barbara County in California encapsulates one of the worst wildfire hazard scenarios affecting highly populated areas along the west coast of the United States. A significant portion of the Santa Barbara population resides in mountain areas near canyons and passes in the wildland-urban interface, and are particularly vulnerable to fires during extreme weather conditions. Residents use winding narrow roads to leave these areas, which increases the time needed for mandatory evacuations. Frequent gusty downslope winds accompanied by rapid warming and decreased relative humidity are among the most significant fire weather conditions affecting coastal Santa Barbara. Such conditions have enhanced the severity of 15 major wildfires since 1955. This project will integrate atmospheric, fire spread and transportation models to enhance the current understanding of extreme fire weather regimes and wildfire behavior in the wildland-urban interface in Santa Barbara County. The main goal of the project is to improve existing fire-weather forecast methods, increase resilience, and reduce socioeconomic impacts of wildfires. The project also will improve understanding of the effects of natural hazards and extreme events on societal preparedness in the context of evacuation planning. The results of the project can be applied to many other mountain areas in Southern California where fires present a major hazard. The project will provide key outreach materials for dissemination to government agencies that could be available to the public. Moreover, the project supports the development of new educational courses, and supports the training of graduate students and a postdoctoral investigator

This project will develop unique approaches to make substantial intellectual advances in a natural hazard problem of high impact to society. The research links fire-weather, fire behavior and evacuation planning and focuses on the coastal area of Santa Barbara County with a population of over 200,000 people. The project will develop a new framework centered on the specific objectives of: 1) understanding synoptic-to-mesoscale mechanisms of downslope windstorms and extreme fire-weather regimes (i.e., gusty winds, low humidity, high temperature and high vegetation fuels), 2) investigating probabilities of fire spread and fire-weather risk at the wildland-urban interface, 3) developing enhanced evacuation strategies using transportation and land use models and 4) carrying on a comprehensive program to transfer research findings to Federal, State and Local Agencies and the community of Santa Barbara. This research will create scenarios to examine evacuation strategies using transportation modeling, significantly enhancing understanding of extreme fire weather regimes on various spatial and temporal scales and improving the present capability to model and forecast these hazardous events.

por.por_cntn:
Santa Barbara County (SB) in Southern California is a wildfire prone region. Coastal communities are particularly exposed to wildfire hazards as most of the population lives in a narrow zone between the mountains and the ocean, with a growing number of people living in the wildland-urban-interface (WUI). Residents in these areas use winding, narrow roads to exit their homes, increasing the time necessary for mandatory evacuations. Gusty and dry downslope windstorms on the lee of the Santa Ynez Mountains (named Sundowner winds) are the most significant fire weather conditions affecting coastal SB. The resilience of local Fire agencies and population to such hazardous situations is limited in scope and this project have addressed some of these important issues. This research integrated a multi-model approach to investigate 1) Sundowner mechanisms and predictability; 2) Wildfire spread and risk in the wildland-urban interface (WUI); 3) evacuation capabilities in Santa Barbara. The broad impact of this study was to build a new framework to collaborate with the National Weather Service (office in LA/Oxnard – NWS LOX) and with decision makers and first responders in the Santa Barbara and Montecito Fire Departments. This was done through numerous approaches. For instance, daily 84h weather forecast at 2km resolution focusing on Santa Barbara and Ventura have been are publicly available and can be FTP transferred to the NWS. Based on our research and fostered collaborations with the NWS/LOX we developed new graphic tools focusing on unique dynamical aspects of these winds aiming to improve red-flag warnings and other hazards associated with Sundowners.

  Our research utilized multiple methodologies and produced unique data sets. We created a 32yrs (1987-2019), hourly, 1km grid resolution downscaling with the Weather Research & Forecast (WRF) model with a domain covering Santa Barbara and Ventura County that is now available to the public (under request). This data set was utilized to investigate Sundowner mechanisms, and also to understand the complex climatology of these events.  To support these results, we developed studies using remote automatic weather stations with more than 5yrs of data sets and the wind profiler at the Santa Barbara airport to investigate diurnal cycles of meteorological variables and how they change during Sundowner winds. We also evaluated the performance of simple fire spread models (FARSITE and Flamap) in accurately simulating fire perimeters during Sundowners by simulating two major wildfires that quickly spread toward populated areas of SB.  We proposed a novel method to evaluate wildfire risk in the WUI above Santa Barbara and Montecito that considers patterns of ignitions in the region. According to data provided by the SB County Fire department, the majority of ignitions of previous wildfires in SB are of anthropogenic origin, and they tend to be clustered around roads and trails in the region. Based on these results, we proposed new methods to investigate the probability of wildfires in the WUI that accounts for the probability of ignitions around this complex network of roads and trails. We performed 900 simulations of wildfires based on three distinct ignition models and three distinct weather scenarios. These scenarios included mean atmospheric conditions during non-Sundowners, average conditions during Sundowners, and the worst-case scenario of a Sundowner observed in the 32yrs of WRF simulations. This approach demonstrated that the probability of wildfires is not homogeneous on the southern slopes of the Santa Ynez Mountains, pointing out the need for adequate infrastructure in some specific regions where simulations have repeatedly shown large exposure to fast-spreading wildfires. A detailed evacuation modeling was performed in some locations, focusing on mobile homes where we observe large concentration of people and where quick evacuation might be necessary during a wildfire. These models evaluated the time necessary to evacuate these communities, indicating that more than an hour might be necessary, considering the density of people and cars. These results were published in nine articles (some coauthored by NWS forecasters and SB fire marshals and Montecito Fire Department fuel specialist) and one book chapter. Results of this research were shared with decision makers during workshops and with the Santa Barbara community in panel meetings. Moreover, principal investigators incorporated results in their courses on mountain meteorology at UCSB and SJSU. The lead PI created lectures that are now incorporated in an online course on disaster resilience offered by the University of California, Berkley to all University of California undergraduate students.  Principal investigators, students and the postdoc presented their works in conferences, workshops and invited talks.  The Principal Investigator created a webpage to educate the population on Sundowners and their importance in fast-wildfire spreading. Other outreach activities included public talks in local venues (pubs, museum, etc), and in schools. Results from this study are published in 2 PhD dissertations, one MA thesis and one M.Sc. dissertation. The project employed one postdoc and one project scientist.
